Let's start with a confession. When Rome Total War was released I didn't buy it, didn't play it. Turn based sounded boring, I wanted real-time because that was cool. So when did I first play it? After Rome 2 was announced, I wanted to play with the ancient world but release was still months away. Then the release was utter garbage. Thus I turned to Rome Total War.  So lets start with the TL;DR part. Good: The feel of combat. It's not fast, a bit to slow but formations collide.  Good: Size, this game is huge. Large amount of provinces as well as factions. Improvement over Shogun 2, stuck in Japan. Good: Atmosphere, Senate missions as Rome, three seperate factions. Lots of different other factions too. Good: Mods, mods, mods. There some excellent mods out there for this game.  Bad: Graphics, the graphics sure aged. Then again it's an old 3D game, they rarely age well. Bad: AI, AI isn't the smartest. The game is easily gamed, then again newer Total War's still are. Bad: Egypt. Egypt was greek at the time, not pharaohs, well not styled like the rulers of old. Just graphics but I'll mention it anyway. Bad: Resolution, no real widescreen support and no 1080p at all. Highest I can get is 1600x1400.  So should I still get it? Well it's different for sure. I got into it after I played Medieval 2, Empire, Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai. I could make the journey back and was pleasantly suprised. On the other hand my main gaming PC wasn't very available at the time and I played mostly on a laptop. So older games was something I was stuck with either way.  Give it a shot if you like ancient history, a slower strategy game and long battles. If you like historical accuraccy give Europa Barborium a spin. From a pure gameplay perspective it has an overwhelming amount of units, recruitment, moving and battles take ages but it's sure authentic.  This is a great game, it has aged but not to much. It's deep but not to deep and I'm sort of sad the path Total War games have been taken lately. Still we can go back to this and I recommend you do that.

As the user-defined tags suggest this is a historical strategy game. The overworld campaign is a turn-based grand strategy- sort of a simplified Civilization. The battles are mostly real time, with a toggle for 2x or 3x, so I guess it could be argued there is a 4x element to the battle.  The campaign takes a long time to finish, but it is good training if you want to play multiplayer. There are some troops that don't seem to be very good relative to their costs- I'm thinking the Arcanii (why only 16????????!!!!!!!!!!), but for the most part the game seems pretty balanced.  The biggest downside for me was the fact that this game crashes every 4th or 5th battle, and I hear I am not the only person who has this problem. The public order system can also be wonky- I lost a settlement to a gladiator revolt, then recaptured it and two turns later there was another gladiator revolt with the exact same amount of gladiators.   Overall, I would strongly reccomend this game if you like the idea of massive battles, tactical thinking, or time consuming strategic considerations. I know I loved it.

This game is amazing, that simply said. Yeah I understand, it's almost ten years old, but when did graphics ever matter? What it lacks in that department it makes up for in gameplay and sheer depth, and I don't know if you'll agree with me on this one, but is it just me that's thinking the Total War games are losing their charm with every new realese? I mean, you saw Empire, and sure, CA had the excuse of a new engine, but then they realesed that absolute mess that was Rome II (and I always thought the sequels were supposed to be better) I was appalled at what I was seeing, and henceforth opted never to purchase it.  Rome I is (in my opinion)   the   greatest Total War game made, and one of the best strategy games I've ever played. The amount of detail that CA put into the game is incredible, and better still, installing DarthMod to your game ever more makes the playing experience one to remember. Sure, the A.I is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible, but that never bothered me (just made Rome easier to capture). I can remember once, I had a small force of perhaps five-hundred professional, highly trained and disciplined Legionaries with me, to defend against an army of over three-thousand mindless barbarians. It was these battles that made the game so enjoyable, the sheer tension in the middle of a pitched battle, when neither side show signs of winning, is it going to be yours? Or the enemy's? And aside from the few small skirmishes between armies, when you give your opponent time to assemble a massive force, and you ride out to meet that force with your own, it's a ♥♥♥♥ing bloodbath (serious, the amount of corpses left on the sand was immense). As I've mentioned before, the battles are intense, oh, and, did I mention that the battles were intense?  With the expansions being 'Alexander' and 'Barbarian Invasion', these further build upon the gameplay. Offering you to play as the young Greek King as he forges his mighty path of blood and conquest against the Persians for control. Or giving you the chance to save the crumbling Roman Empire in a last attempt to drive out the hordes of invading Huns and Goths, and several other European barbarian tribes.   I myself, never played much of the Alexander expansion, I've only sunk as little as a few hours into it. As for Barbarian Invasion however, that, that is a completely different story. I thoroughly enjoyed this expansion to the already great game.   That said. Rome I is a great game, one I have played for hours on end, and was never bored with it.  I give this game a 9.5/10

It's still a remarkably pretty game, and although the unit geometry is a bit angular when zoomed in it holds its own in creating an attractive world, with none of the over-sharpness that is plaguing the later games in the Total War series. There are frustrations though, especially with large unit sizes causing major pathfinding errors in siege battles.  If you somehow haven't played it yet then it's a must-buy. I bought this then-cutting-edge game back when it was released in 2004. I'd seen it advertised some months before that on a TV series that used its engine wherein two teams competed against each other to win an historical battle. That whetted my appetite enormously. When I bought it, I not only spent countless hours playing but also played its add-ons (Barbarian Invasion and Alexander). To me Rome: Total War was the best of the Total War series - a balance between the old 2D strategy of Medieval: Total War and the increasingly eye-candy iterations that came thereafter (though I think Medieval 2: Total War was also very good). Add to this the fact that Rome has more mods than any other in that series (and with more diversity of setting/theme) and you have a game that is highly replayable. I still dip into it after 11 years of owning it! Rome forums still remain populated after all this time, and mods are still being developed for it. That speaks volumes. I've had the pleasure of being a RTW modder myself which has only added to the great joy this game has brought. Give it a go. You won't regret it.

Ah, Rome. I never played it at launch or for years after the fact, but it was always on my friends computer. Which he was of course one of those little wank-jobs that always showed off his ♥♥♥♥ but never shared it.   No, about 2012 was really the first time I got to play R:TW, my first TW title being Medieval 2.   Nowadays, people often say just get EB or any of the number of great mods. However, we're talking about Rome here, the base game as presented on Steam.  First off, with this purchase you get both Rome 1 (which follows Roman history from before the first Punic War to the early Imperial age) and the expansion Barbarian Invasion (which follows, of course, the invasions of barbarian tribes during the decline of the Roman empire). You don't receive the expansion Alexander (the campaigns of Alexander the Great) but of all the Rome expansions- Alexander is often regarded as the poorest by both critics and fans.  Rome 1 provides all the basics of a TW title. A campaign map where you conquer a part of the world. A skirmish game-mode where you fight the AI in a battle of choice. And Multiplayer (Now patched for steamworks as of 2014). Barbarian Invasion supplies the same package.  Within the Campaign Map you choose one of three Roman Families at first. This is where I start to have some gripes with Rome. For one, you have to conquer the other factions to unlock them in the grand campaign. Two, even if you just edit the .ini files to unlock them, the campaign is heavily focused on Rome. They get the most units, the most mechanics, the most events, and the most progression. While it's perfectly possible to enjoy playing the underpowered Gauls, I find these other factions to be relatively abandoned by CA. Some factions feel relatively the same, such as the Gauls and Germans, with only minor unit variations to give some feel to them. Also of note is that some factions are simply over-powered beyond conceivable belief. Units such as Rome's Urban Cohorts are just horrifying when placed against the AI. This can make Rome somewhat of a snooze-fest once the Marius Reforms activates and you start to get the best of the Roman crop. Other factions such as Gaul have laughably garbage infantry for the most part. While some argue historical accuracy, I find it harms the game balance and the ultimate enjoyment available. But a discussion on Rome's balance is way beyond the scope of this review, suffice it to say, Rome is unbalanced- but it rarely matters in single player.  If however you only care for Rome, then RTW is for you. Each of the three families starts with an 'obvious' foe and paths of expansion. The Senate functions as a uniting force, rewarding you for following orders, showing disapproval when you fail. The whole game is built around your family as you grow both your empire and your influence. The game provides some great role-play as you follow the Senate's orders, checking to see if the masses or the patricians prefer you. As you progress, so will your power- inevitably enraging the Senate. It's moments like these where the campaign starts to shine. While I won't spoiler where that ultimately leads to, it justifies the slow start to the Imperial campaign.  Speaking of the campaigning, the conquest of towns is fought on the battle map. Here you command your army, including your general if he's there, and engage the enemy. This is where the meat of the game is, and here where Total War makes its name. The battles are some of the fastest in the series, with units moving rapidly and viciously. Veteran units can stomp multiple newbie corps single-handedly. A single cavalry charge can lead to a rapid route. All this occurs to the excellent soundtrack of Jeff van Dyck and combat mechanics that (mostly) stand the test of time.  I have a gripes here when compared to the later Total War games. For one, field battles (where units meet with no city or the like nearby) are unfortunately not too common in the later stages of the Campaign. This is due to the AI choosing the hide in cities. Due to this, you get to meet the siege battles of Rome- which are terrible. I'm not going to dance around this issue, siege battles are awful. The path finding of your units is all sorts of agony, and it only gets worse if you fight civilized nations that have large, built-up cities. You can have entire units enter into embarrassing formations where a handful of men are trying to take down a hoplite wall. It's funny, but it's hell. Siege battles can be ignored due to the great auto-resolve system Rome has, which can be used for field battles too.  Unfortunately, I have issues with unit path-finding in general. Cavalry especially is very cumbersome compared to later titles. You will just have to get used with Cav occasionally ignoring your orders and charging head-long into spear-walls instead of between that wide-gap in the line. Also, units randomly charging other units instead of the ones you ordered them to is also common- this includes cav. It makes the control feel archaic, and from what I've researched it just seems to be a bug with the formations. It's annoying and often makes me just go towards Medieval 2 and download a Rome mod (EB2, I'm forever hyped). It isn't game-breaking since the AI is just...  Meet CA's AI, from Rome to Rome 2 you're going to be playing with him. He's mentally insane, tuned seemingly for players that have no clue about formation tactics. The moment you figure out strategy, is the moment you realize that the AI is helplessly innocent, inept, incapable of learning, a terrible judge in terrain choice, a terrible flanker, and perhaps suicidal to boot. He's come in many different flavors- but really only modders seem capable of making him remotely competent. Increasing the difficulty will not make him smarter, only gives him a boost in unit stats. For a newbie, he's a good first opponent for casual player, but he won't teach you anything.  What is not a flaw of the series is its presentation. Rome's simplistic art direction may have aged polygonal graphics but it still holds up relatively well, appearing distinguished and fluid despite being a game from 2004. It's a standard that's been kept by just about every title. The music, which I've only mentioned once, is some of the best in the series, bringing a lot of those aged graphics to life with broad stroke of tunes. Even the voice-acting has some charm, in the hammy sense.  But we're not done, BI rounds out our package by being ♥♥♥♥ing painful. It's a campaign for barbarian lovers giving great variety to the barbars while still making Rome a fun faction. Notably a bit more balanced in the campaign the Western Rome campaign is one of the hardest challenges in TW history. It's meant only for series vets, even then it's infamous for the horror it gives. My personal opinion of it is that it's hard in the arbitrary sense, with unrest and religion stacking the deck on you. The AI isn't any smart notably (can land units by sea if the stars align). Most of the difficulty comes from rebellions, but the various barbarian tribes declaring war on you adds some fun. This campaign is historically inaccurate in it's portrayal of what troubled Rome. This is mostly due to the engine being incapable of modeling certain things. Historical inaccuracy is just a common thing in TW as it is- but I'm someone capable of ignoring this in favor of fun. BI besides the difficulty, is a neat addition to Rome and where I say barbarian lovers should go in lieu of the RTW.  Still, RTW offers a great package for TW newbs. Introducing you to the series with a game that still holds up, with great modding potential. For the gripes I have, RTW is still a great game. If you have to choose a TW, go with an era that interests you most. All of them have pros and cons. Between Rome 1 and 2? You get a complete product with R1 that is fully patched and 'done'. No dlcs, no patches ruining your mods, same era.

ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!  Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.   It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies and capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.  This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.  The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a  second expansion-slash-DLC  available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.   The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three  gens  that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.  There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.   I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine Creative Assembly intended for Napoleonic warfare.

My biggest 2 issues with this game:  Campaign: Holding large territories is virtually impossible due to unrest, I guess that is historically accurate (even on easy), but counter-intuitive to your objectives.  Battles: Unit and camera control are both a disaster. Why they decided against a traditional RTS camera (even though there is an RTS camera option in the game) is beyond me. Moving the mouse to the sides rotates the camera instead of scrolling the map...same goes for the arrow keys. Units themselves are hard to control and rarely do what you tell them to. Want your cavalry to attack a certain squad from behind? Well, first you have manually move them to avoid all other enemies in sight and then they may still attack the wrong enemy. Battles frequently look like masses of pixels trying to get to the enemy, but the game engine doesn't allow that.  A good example of how to do it right would be Dawn of War. Here units first engage in ranged combat, but when they are forced into melee they are actively looking for a direct opponent instead of creating 2 big masses of armies that patiently wait until the front line disintegrates. You can micro manage some of that, but honestly, it's really annoying and just lazy in my opinion.  Apart from that the game is actually pretty good if you're looking for Grand Strategy and the historic battles you can replay from the menu are fun and challenging, but also give you interesting info about what happened back then.

Anyway Rome total war is an excellent game, tatics while rather straightforward most of the time are realistic and you need to have a basic understanding of strategy to beat the AI on anything above easy. Every faction has different unit compositions to use so your tatics will have to change on subsequent playthroughs. Basically Rome Total war has a stunning amount of depth and historical accuracy put into it. While the graphics don't hold up a decade later, the gameplay is superior to even the sequel Rome TW 2 which came out several months ago. This game is worth the full price even today, and if your looking to get into total war, or getting your friends into total war, this is a great starting point or gift respectively. To give you some basic tatics, rome's usual goal is to when not facing phalanxes just mash your infantry into the enemy, as your infantry are essentially the greatest in the world. While there is more to it then that namely using light infantry to hold your flanks whilst heavy infantry splits the enemy down the center, using your cavaly to take out enemy seige weapons or to flank a phalanx, thats all there is to it. When playing as greece your goal is to not get flanked, as you have the most powerful phalanxes in the world and will almost never lose if you don't get flanked. Carthages goal is to use elephants and support cavalry to literaly blow holes in the enemy line and crush enemy morale, whilst your infantry pin the enemies center or flanks in place, depending on the lay of the land. If your parthia you want to make the enemy chase you and use hit and run tactics as you have the best cavalry in the world, and the greatest horse archers to ever live. and so on. Total war is a cross between Turn Based Strategy and Real Time Strategy genres, sadly it fails at both. The fights are bland and unless you really enjoy spending 45 minutes of mind numbing unit micromanagement for each battle you'll just let the AI auto resolve conflicts. All you are left with is a mediocre turn based campaign map with military centric building like which barely rivals browser based RTS MMOs (The mechanics are really that simplistic).   I've only put in a few hours on this game because honestly I don't see the point. From the very start I had problems with the game, glitchy problems. The tutorial cannot be saved; if you can't sit down and play it for 1 hour straight just forget about the tutorial unless you want to leave the game running in the taskbar while you are away. Then, when I finally got the time to play it for one hour straight, the camera glitched and kept panning to the lower right corner of the map. Since I couldn't save the tutorial I had to quit and start it all over AGAIN for the third time.   So I'm through the tutorial, now what? Time to conquer the known ancient world for the glory of Rome! Woot! Three battles later and my mind is changed, this is just boring and pointless. Every battle seems to be pretty much the same, you set up units and let the killing commence. Unit collision never seems to work and in R:TW it means your units behave like daft plebeians; trying to get them all through a gate, ha, half of them always split off and the rest of the time what? Do you really enjoy watching 1000 virtual units fail at each incessantly until the other unit's demise? How about friendly fire? Good stuff right? Your archers mowing down your own army because you forgot to click each archer 'card' and tell them to stop it! How about a real cool zoomed in shot with arrows flying into the camera, cool right?!   It is cool the first couple of times but the *cool* factor wears off real quick and you are left struggling to control 1k units who are completely lost without your incessant management.   The main map is really no better, it's even more focused on military then your run of the mill RTS. I was really hoping for something more akin to Civilization in depth where you actually gather multiple resources and manage your production but here all that seems to matter is hording gold through exorbitant taxes. This way you build more boring buildings that your citizens need to be happy so you can train more boring armies so you can fight more boring battles at the Senate's behest. Are you bored yet?   I think the original title for this game must have been 'Rome: Realistic Battle Simulator' but when first screened to an audience the reception was lukewarm so they changed it to something sexier.   TLDR, Unless you really enjoy overly simplistic empire management where every RTS battle is 30 minutes or more of the exact same assault plan I recommend you pass on this glorified combat simulator.
